revised_title: Disturbance and Recovery in Tropical Rain Forests: Germination and Growth of Colonizing Species in Artificial Gaps
tldr: This study investigates the germination and growth of colonizing species in artificial gaps of different sizes in a dipterocarp rainforest in Sabah, Malaysia. The research found that germination was not significantly affected by gap size, but was increased by soil exposure or disturbance. The results suggest that gap size may not influence the composition of colonizing vegetation by controlling seed germination, but an effect operating through differential mortality cannot be ruled out.
